column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.DemoNERRE|NamedentityTags
#T_RL=webanno.custom.DemoRE|NamedentityRelations|BT_webanno.custom.DemoNERRE
#Text=Superconducting wires of (Ba,Na)Fe2As2 were fabricated by ex situ powder-in-tube (PIT) method.
#Text=In the present studies, polycrystalline powders of (Ba,Na)Fe2As2 were prepared by two different ways of solid-state reaction.
#Text=In the first method, Ba pieces, Na ingots, Fe powder, and As pieces were used as starting materials.
#Text=The starting mixture contained 15% excess Na and 5% excess As, to compensate the loss of elements.

#Text=After filing Ba pieces from the chunk and crushing of As pieces, starting materials were mixed for more than 10 h in Ar atmosphere using a planetary ball-milling machine and densely packed into a niobium tube.
#Text=The niobium tube was then put into a stainless steel tube and sealed in argon-filled glove box for heat treatment for 30 h at 800, 850, and 900°C.
#Text=It was then ground into powder using an agate mortar in an argon-filled glove box.
#Text=We designate the powder that was heated at 850°C as the #1 powder.
#Text=In the second method, BaAs, NaAs and Fe2As were used as precursors to synthesize (Ba,Na)Fe2As2.
#Text=For BaAs, a flat-plate Ba was finely cut into small pieces.
#Text=They were weighed out with As in total of ~2 g, and sealed in an evacuated quartz tube.
#Text=It was heated for 20 h at 700°C, after intermediate heating for 10 h at 500°C.
#Text=For NaAs, Na and As were weighed out in total of ~1 g, and they were put in an alumina crucible, and then put in a stainless steel tube, and sealed in an argon-filled glove box.
#Text=After intermediate heating for 10 h at 500°C, it was heated for 24 h at 800°C.
#Text=For Fe2As, Fe and As were weighed out in total of ~3 g, and sealed in an evacuated quartz tube.
#Text=After an intermediate heating for 10 h at 500°C, it was heated for 40 h at 800°C.
#Text=The prepared precursors were weighed to a composition of BaAs:NaAs:Fe2As = 0.6:(0.4+):1, thoroughly mixed.
#Text=Here, ( = 0.1) is additional NaAs content to compensate the loss of Na and As during the synthesis.
#Text=Polycrystalline powders were synthesized for 24 h at 820°C in an alumina crucible which was enclosed in an argon-filled stainless steel tube.
#Text=We designate thus obtained powder as the #2.
#Text=The obtained two kinds of powders were ground and filled into silver tubes with outer and inner diameters of 4.5 mm and 3 mm, respectively.
#Text=Ag tube filled with the #1 powder was cold-drawn using dies with circular holes.
#Text=On the other hand, the tube filled with the #2 powder was swaged using a rotary swaging machine.
#Text=These wires were formed into a round shape with a diameter of ∼1.5 mm for the #1 wire, and ~1.35 mm for the #2 wire, respectively.
#Text=After cutting them into short pieces, one of the pieces was put into 1/8 inch copper tube and redrawn into a square shape with a groove roller down to a diagonal dimension of 1.2 mm.
#Text=After the drawing process, both ends of the wire were sealed using an arc welder.
#Text=The sealed wires were sintered using the HIP technique.
#Text=Wires were heated for 4 h at 700°C in an argon atmosphere under different pressures of 0.1–175 MPa.
#Text=HIP processes under the highest pressure 175 MPa were performed at National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology or Metal Technology Co.
#Text=Ltd..
#Text=Others were performed at the University of Tokyo.
#Text=Obtained HIP wires using the #1 and #2 powders are designated as the #1 and #2 wires, respectively.
#Text=In order to evaluate the transport Jc , a DC electric current up to 100 A was delivered through the wire at a ramping rate of 50–100 Amin−1 .
#Text=In order to minimize the effect of Joule heating at the current leads, measurements were performed in liquid helium.
#Text=The current density when the electric field exceeds 1 Vcm-1 is defined as the transport Jc .
